thread.title: Christian Hackenberg leads Penn State to big win over Indiana
thread.title_full: Christian Hackenberg leads Penn State to big win over Indiana

author: Mark Wogenrich
title: Christian Hackenberg leads Penn State to big win over Indiana
text:
(Mark Wogenrich) 
Sacked in the first quarter by Indiana linebacker Tegray Scales, Hackenberg fumbled and the Hoosiers recovered. But an Indiana penalty for illegal hands to the face negated the fumble and gave Penn State a first down at the 49-yard line. 
Two plays later, Hackenberg hit freshman Brandon Polk on a beautifully conceived jet-screen release for a touchdown, giving the Lions a 7-0 lead. The sequence enraged Indiana coach Kevin Wilson, whose team also entered the game 4-1. 
"I thought we were ready to go, but at the same time there was just a little bit more selfishness with our actions today, just playing and functioning as a football team," Wilson said. "Today, Penn State was a much better football team across the board." 
In the second quarter, Hackenberg connected on a squarely thrown touchdown pass to DaeSean Hamilton, who knew his post route would be open as soon as he beat the cornerback off the line. That 39-yard touchdown pass began a run of 22 unanswered points for Penn State to take over the game. 
Perhaps an even bigger revelation, however, was Hackenberg's running, particularly in the second half. The 6-4, 230-pound quarterback flustered Indiana by ditching the pocket to scramble on several occasions. 
Among his run were a 22-yarder (a career-long) and two for scores, one of which he capped with a McGloinesque dive. On the other, Hackenberg eschewed throwing to a wide-open Carter in favor of the safe rushing touchdown. 
Fittingly, the last time a Penn State quarterback had two rushing touchdowns in a game was McGloin against Illinois in 2012. Last week, quarterbacks coach Ricky Rahne hinted that Hackenberg might run more Saturday —"When it's there, I would love to see him take off," Rahne said — and the quarterback saw the lanes. 
Interestingly, that also hinted to how successful Penn State's offense could be with a quarterback who can turn broken plays into first downs. 
"W talked to a lot of people in the off-season, and everybody talks about two first downs," Franklin said. "If a quarterback can get two first downs a game for you with his legs, you're going to be in a really good position. Christian was able to do that." 
After the game, Franklin was feeling good, too. The Lions swept their stretch of five home games and will take a 5-1 record to Ohio State next week. 
As a result, he joked that Penn State played "ugly football" the past four weeks simply to bloom on Saturday against Indiana. Further, he suggested (sarcastically) that Penn State would reshape Hackenberg into a new role. 
"I think now," Franklin said, "we will have conversations about him being a dual-threat quarterback and installing the option."
